Chat with an OpenAI model using the responses API

Source: R/provider-openai-responses.R
chat_openai_responses.Rd

The responses API is the latest interface to OpenAI's models. You will need to use it if you want to access the built-in tools like image generation and web search.

Note that a ChatGPT Plus membership does not grant access to the API. You will need to sign up for a developer account (and pay for it) at the developer platform.

Usage

chat_openai_responses(
  system_prompt = NULL,
  base_url = Sys.getenv("OPENAI_BASE_URL", "https://api.openai.com/v1"),
  api_key = openai_key(),
  model = NULL,
  params = NULL,
  api_args = list(),
  api_headers = character(),
  echo = c("none", "output", "all")
)

Arguments

system_prompt

A system prompt to set the behavior of the assistant.

base_url

The base URL to the endpoint; the default uses OpenAI.

api_key

API key to use for authentication.

You generally should not supply this directly, but instead set the OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable. The best place to set this is in .Renviron, which you can easily edit by calling usethis::edit_r_environ().

model

The model to use for the chat (defaults to "gpt-4.1"). We regularly update the default, so we strongly recommend explicitly specifying a model for anything other than casual use. Use models_openai() to see all options.

params

Common model parameters, usually created by params().

api_args

Named list of arbitrary extra arguments appended to the body of every chat API call. Combined with the body object generated by ellmer with modifyList().

api_headers

Named character vector of arbitrary extra headers appended to every chat API call.

echo

One of the following options:

  • none: don't emit any output (default when running in a function).

  • output: echo text and tool-calling output as it streams in (default when running at the console).

  • all: echo all input and output.

Note this only affects the chat() method.

Value

A Chat object.

See also

Other chatbots: chat_anthropic(), chat_aws_bedrock(), chat_azure_openai(), chat_cloudflare(), chat_databricks(), chat_deepseek(), chat_github(), chat_google_gemini(), chat_groq(), chat_huggingface(), chat_mistral(), chat_ollama(), chat_openai(), chat_openrouter(), chat_perplexity(), chat_portkey()

Examples

chat <- chat_openai_responses()
#> Using model = "gpt-4.1".
chat$chat("
  What is the difference between a tibble and a data frame?
  Answer with a bulleted list
")
#> - **Printing behavior**:  
#>   - **Data frame:** Prints the entire dataset, which can be 
#> overwhelming for large datasets.  
#>   - **Tibble:** Prints only the first 10 rows and as many columns as 
#> fit on the screen, providing a cleaner, more readable output.
#> 
#> - **Column types**:  
#>   - **Data frame:** Converts character vectors to factors by default 
#> (unless `stringsAsFactors = FALSE` is set).  
#>   - **Tibble:** Never changes column types automatically; character 
#> vectors remain as characters.
#> 
#> - **Subsetting**:  
#>   - **Data frame:** Returns a vector when selecting a single column 
#> using single brackets (e.g., `df[, 1]`).  
#>   - **Tibble:** Always returns a tibble, even when selecting a single 
#> column.
#> 
#> - **Partial matching**:  
#>   - **Data frame:** Allows partial matching of column names, which may
#> cause unexpected behavior.  
#>   - **Tibble:** Never does partial matching of column names; always 
#> requires exact matches.
#> 
#> - **Row names**:  
#>   - **Data frame:** Supports row names.  
#>   - **Tibble:** Does not use row names.
#> 
#> - **Performance**:  
#>   - **Data frame:** Base R structure, can be slower for certain 
#> operations with large datasets.  
#>   - **Tibble:** Optimized for modern workflows (though both are 
#> similar for most basic uses).
#> 
#> - **Package implementation**:  
#>   - **Data frame:** Base R object.  
#>   - **Tibble:** Comes from the `tibble` package, part of the 
#> tidyverse.
#> 
#> - **Creating new columns**:  
#>   - **Data frame:** Can create new columns by reference.  
#>   - **Tibble:** Creating new columns must be done using functions like
#> `mutate()`. 
#> 
#> - **Error messages**:  
#>   - **Data frame:** Sometimes gives less informative error messages.  
#>   - **Tibble:** Offers more user-friendly and clear error messages.
#> 
#> In summary, **tibbles** are a modern reimagining of **data frames** 
#> designed for the tidyverse with enhanced usability, stricter behavior,
#> and more predictable outputs.

chat$chat("Tell me three funny jokes about statisticians")
#> Sure! Here are three funny jokes about statisticians:
#> 
#> 1.  
#> **Why did the statistician drown while crossing a river?**  
#> Because it was, on average, three feet deep!
#> 
#> 2.  
#> **How do you tell the difference between a statistician and a 
#> mortician?**  
#> The statistician is the one who buries the results that can’t be 
#> explained!
#> 
#> 3.  
#> **Why did the statistician bring a ladder to the bar?**  
#> Because he heard the drinks were on the house… but wanted to check the
#> confidence interval first!
